title: Resurfacings
content:
Hatay, Turkey.

JK and the interpreter first met KA, who was then 6 years old, at his home in April 1997. His mother was present for the entire interview. KA claimed to remember a life in Istanbul some 850 km away. He said his family’s name had been Karakas and he had been an Armenian Christian. He was rich and lived in a large three-story house. He said people called him Fistik and his wife and children had Greek first names. He said he and his wife’s wedding took place in Bodrum, a town on the coast approximately 430 km from Istanbul by air. He also said he often carried a large leather bag and he only lived in the house for part of the year. He said he had been shot and killed and his wife was involved in the murder. In addition, he mentioned that his youngest son had died as a rally car driver. 


****


His first resurfacing occurred at the age of two. It became one of Ewen’s mother’s favourite stories to thrill dinner guests with. 

"You won't believe this," Miranda would begin, leaning forward conspiratorially. "Andy and I took little Ewen to Disneyland Paris. He couldn’t even pronounce tomato at that age."

At this point, she'd always stand up, wine glass in hand, using it as a prop.

"So there we are, getting into that boat ride—you know the one with all the singing dolls—and suddenly Ewen starts thrashing around like a caught fish! Out of nowhere!" She'd demonstrate, jerking her body awkwardly. "Then he starts screaming in what sounds like gibberish to us!"

Miranda would lower her voice dramatically, the way I did to impress girls in primary school. "But this young couple nearby, they were Vietnamese or something. They hear him and look horrified. The husband rushes over to me and says, 'Your son is speaking Khmer. He's saying: My wrists, my wrists, untie my wrists. I told you it was an accident. Don't do this, please my wrists. I'll pay you back, you can take my snakeheads. Please NO PLEASE!'"

By this point of the story, Miranda would be face down on the carpet, writhing and holding her arms like a soccer player who had been patted on the back. She would then fall silent, her face hidden from view. After a pause, her silence would become a fit of giggles, breaking into genuine laughter and delight, as she would stand to deliver the grand finale “Who knew our Ewen was already on his second life. Talk about the terrible twos!”


It wasn't a great punchline but when Ewen was younger, he would relish taking part in this retelling with his mother. As soon as he heard his mother begin the now familiar introduction to the story, he would leap from his bed and run into the dining room in his dinosaur pyjamas to offer more details and corrections.


“No Mum, I was Cambodian, not Vietnamese!”

“Snakeheads are a fish, I was the best at catching them, I could do it with my bare hands!”

“They tied my legs too Mum, don’t forget, I couldn’t kick like that!” 


As Ewen got older and more memories of his life as Kosal emerged, he grew less interested in reliving his death of 1912. He would lie in bed listening to his mother launch into the tale and gently rub his wrists, still feeling the coarse rope cutting into his skin. The smell of the oil he used to burn Prak’s fishing nets and boats would sting his nostrils, though he still couldn’t remember why he had done it. He’d close his eyes and see the anger on the faces of the crew as they dragged him from his bed, beat his lean body and bound his limbs. The cold glint of Prak’s eyes as he pushed Kosal overboard, as cold and as black as the water that engulfed him and dragged him down, down…

For their part, the guests would sit in polite, uncomfortable silence as Miranda transformed the living room into the stage for this Cambodian fishing feud. They'd smile weakly, eyes darting nervously, each wondering how a series of small, seemingly sensible decisions had led them to become a captive audience to this one-woman show. After the goodbyes and the goodnights and the we-should-do-this-agains, they'd huddle on the street by their cars, shivering in the Welsh night air, whispering about what had transpired.

"Could it be true?"

"The lad remembers a past life?" 

"Does this mean that God, and Heaven, and Hell, and Salvation, are losing out to some eastern Karmic bosh?”

“What was the name of that boat ride at Disneyland again?”[1] 

Though the questions were heavy and the answers scarce, they would all agree that coming to the widow’s house tonight was a mistake. From the upstairs bedroom window, Miranda would part the curtains ever so slightly, watching the congregation and smiling contentedly to herself.

****

Interviews with 42 adults with past-life memories as children reveal that over one-third of them have retained some of their early childhood memories or  images that they experienced as from a previous life and which often consist of tragic and life-threatening events. - Haraldsson, E. (2008). Persistence of past-life memories: Study of adults who claimed in their childhood to remember a past life. Journal of Scientific Exploration, 22(3), 385-393.

****

Ewen called them “resurfacings” because it wasn’t as if he was being possessed or taken over. The memories started from deep within him and would gently drift to the surface, like my swim trunks that time I tried the high-dive at our local pool. There, they would bob and bubble alongside his present reality for all to see, while he struggled to put them back where they belonged before anybody noticed or peeked underwater.

footnotes.content: Once I met a girl at a bar in Barcelona. She didn’t speak much English and I couldn’t speak Spanish. Despite this, I learned that she loved Disneyland, especially the ride with the boats. She knew the Spanish name for the ride, but to her frustration she just couldn’t quite recall what it was called in English. Fast forward to the end of the night. We’re back at her hotel room. Layers of clothing are coming off until I’m standing in front of her, stark naked. She looks me up and down, sizing me up, and suddenly clicks her fingers and exclaims “OH! It’s a small world after all!”
